title: 111_hr3703
content:
The Act may be cited as the "White House Conference on Autism Act of 2009". The Congress acknowledges the rapid increase in Autism Spectrum Disorders (ASD) in the U.S., with rates now at 1 in 150, leading to a significant financial burden of over $35 billion annually. The epidemic continues to grow, with a new case of autism diagnosed approximately every 20 minutes, surpassing the combined diagnoses of AIDS, diabetes, and cancer in children. Autism is diagnosed every 20 minutes, with more children diagnosed this year than with AIDS, diabetes, and cancer combined. The cost of autism to the nation is over $35 billion annually, expected to increase. It is a life-changing condition that could impact future talent pools in various sectors. Comprehensive research is crucial for understanding autism and other developmental disorders. The Combating Autism Act of 2006 allocated nearly $1 billion for autism research, focusing on environmental factors, treatments, and early identification. A White House Conference on Autism aims to further advance scientific study in this area. A White House Conference on Autism provides an opportunity to advance research on cutting-edge treatments and services for autism, building on the foundation of the Combating Autism Act. The White House Conference on Autism is authorized. The President is required to call the White House Conference on Autism by December 31, 2010, to make policy recommendations on combating the autism epidemic in the United States. The Secretaries of Health and Human Services, Education, and Housing and Urban Development will plan and conduct the Conference to find the underlying cause of autism. The White House Conference on Autism, to be convened by the Secretaries of Health and Human Services, Education, and Housing and Urban Development in consultation with the Surgeon General, aims to galvanize a national effort to find the underlying causes of autism, identify solutions for autistic individuals and their families, chart a research agenda, facilitate a national dialogue, and showcase innovative programs. The White House Conference on Autism aims to address challenges faced by autistic children and their families, highlight innovative programs, and review existing legislation for improving autism research services. The White House Conference on Autism aims to develop specific recommendations for legislative action to enhance the health and well-being of autistic individuals and their families. SEC. 4. SEC. 5. CONFERENCE DELEGATES.

The Cochairs will gather delegates from various backgrounds in autism and neurodevelopmental disorders, including government representatives, professionals, laypeople, and members of the public affected by autism spectrum disorders in the United States. In administering this section, the Cochairs notify Policy Committee members of meetings, seek cooperation from other federal departments, publish a proposed agenda for public comment, and provide necessary background materials for delegates. The Cochairs of the Conference on autism are responsible for preparing background materials, employing necessary personnel, and ensuring the proposed agenda is published in the Federal Register. The Cochairs of the Conference on autism are responsible for ensuring a fair and balanced representation of views among employed personnel and preventing inappropriate influence on recommendations. The Cochairs of the Conference on autism are responsible for ensuring unbiased representation and preventing undue influence on recommendations. They must provide delegates with current statistical data and information on autism spectrum disorders in the US before the Conference convenes. The Cochairs are authorized to accept gifts on behalf of the United States. The Cochairs of the Conference on autism can accept gifts on behalf of the United States, including cash or in-kind donations. These gifts must be used to carry out the Act and can be earmarked for specific purposes. The Cochairs are required to maintain records of the sources, amounts, and uses of gifts accepted, as well as the recipients of assistance and the amount received by each person. SEC. 7. REPORT OF THE CONFERENCE. The Policy Committee must prepare a preliminary report on the Conference within 100 days of adjournment, to be published in the Federal Register and sent to state chief executive officers. States must submit their views on the report within 45 days. A final report, including state executives' views, must be prepared within 6 months of adjournment and submitted to the President and Congress. The Policy Committee compiles views and findings of state chief executive officers, prepares a report with recommendations for administrative action and legislation, to be published in the Federal Register and sent to the President and Congress. SEC. 8. STATUS REPORTS.

The Surgeon General must prepare and publish a status report on the implementation of recommendations from the final report within 2 years of the Conference adjournment. The Comptroller General must also prepare and publish subsequent status reports every 5 years until all recommendations are achieved. These reports will be transmitted to the President and Congress. SEC. 9. DEFINITION OF STATE. The term "State" in this Act refers to several States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, Guam, American Samoa, the Virgin Islands, or the Northern Mariana Islands. SEC. 10. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Authorization is granted for necessary funds to carry out the Act, with limitations on new spending authority. Funds appropriated and received as gifts are available for use, except as specified. Authorization is granted for necessary funds to carry out the Act, with limitations on new spending authority. Funds appropriated and received as gifts are available for use until the expiration of a 1-year period, after which unspent funds are returned to the Treasury unless a trust fund is established. If the Conference on Autism is not convened before December 31, 2010, a trust fund will be established with funds available only for a future conference.
